results.title: Ordinary extraordinary stories
results.brief_description: Ordinary Extraordinary stories features a selection of digital stories produced as part of ACMI digital storytelling public workshop program. This collection celebrates the extraordinary stories of ordinary people. The stories are as diverse as the people who have created them

results.title: The Pier
results.brief_description: Short film shot 1990 on Super 8 Film of St Kilda Pier (burnt down 2003). Filmed early in the morning, the moody feel of the work is heightened by atmospheric soundtrack (added by ACMI) Captures the shared experience of a morning spent at this popular spot for St Kilda residents.

results.title: The Great Sea Explorer
results.brief_description:
The story of Matthew Flinders and his journey to Australia. After leaving his family in England, Flinders sets off to sea, and after many years travelling to and around Australia, he returns home. His heroic journey is rewarded by the Queen with a house as a gift for his exploration achievements.

An animated short entered to “Create a Stamp Story” section of ACMI’s ‘Screen It’ media making competition for Primary Schools.

results.title: A Day in the Life of Captain Cook
results.brief_description:
A reenactment of Captain Cook and his crew hitting land after a treacherous arrival to a new island, later named Botany Bay.

An animated short entered to “Create a Stamp Story” section of ACMI’s ‘Screen It’ media making competition for Primary Schools.

results.title: Fairytales and Fantasy Workshops: Carlton North Primary 18 July 2005: Groups A and B
results.brief_description:
Fairy Tales and Fantasy is an ACMI screen education program designed to encourage students to begin to develop an appreciation for the art and the craft behind moving image in its many forms, by developing their ability to think beyond the screen. Fairy Tales and Fantasy aims to develop students’ understanding of ways in which film-makers create screen texts. Students in Years 1-2 learn about:
- three key stages of plot development
- main elements of the fairy tale genre
- simple concepts related to camera use such as framing, shot types, angles
- the magic of blue-screen technology
- become actors in a short film during a blue-screen workshop that allows them to place themselves in a magical, fairy tale setting
- engage with a film program featuring traditional and non-traditional fairy tales, and participate in a related discussion
- learn some simple editing skills while they create a fairy tale story
- view their ACMI creations.
Fairy Tales and Fantasy and activities provided in the accompanying Teacher Kit are designed to assist students to develop a range of Screen Literacy outcomes. The program is also designed to assist students to develop understandings about the ways in which stories help us to make sense of the world and our place in that world. People all over the world tell stories in many different ways using oral, written and visual texts. This program and related activities enables students to share their experiences of story and to extend and refine their understandings by comparing a range of fairy tale and fantasy texts, analysing narrative structure and exploring animation and film adaptations of fairy tales.

results.title: Back to the past: Westbourne Grammar School
results.brief_description:
Back to the Past or “Screening Melbourne” is designed to encourage students to develop an appreciation for the art and the craft behind moving image in its many forms by developing their ability to think beyond the screen. In the program Students become actors in a sci-fi time travel film story during a blue-screen workshop that allows them to place themselves in a historical Melbourne setting, engage with a screening program featuring historical Melbourne footage and participate in a related discussion
learn some simple editing skills while they create a digital ‘Melbourne travelogue’
Back to the Past aims to develop students’ understanding of ways in which film-makers create screen texts to target particular audiences. Students in Years 3-4 learn about concepts related to camera use such as framing, shot types, and angles as well as some of the features of documentary and blue-screen technology.
Features Charles “Bud” Tingwell

results.title: Get in the picture at ACMI - Open House 25-7-04
results.brief_description: The results of July 2004’s Open House weekend program ‘In the Picture’ - a free taste of our popular Screen Adventures Program. Members of the public were invited to walk on and act up in front of ACMI’s blue screen ‘film genre’ sets.

results.title: Talks: a Natimuk Primary School animation
results.creator_credit: Dave Jones and Natimuk Primary School
results.brief_description: A collaboration between students from Natimuk Primary School and animation artists Dave Jones funded as part of the Arts Victoria Artists in Schools program. Hand drawn crayon drawings are animated and Combined with recorded soundgrabs from the kids to make an engaging sequence of simple, colourful character studies!
